subject: Re: [junit] Re: JavaDocs
msgSnippet: ... Interesting idea.  Off the cuff, I can envision a tool that inspects test methods and adds an @see JavaDoc comment to the corresponding method.  This
messageBody:
Jeremy Thornton wrote:

> Does anyone structure their tests to make them more useful as documentation
> ? I would be a lot more convinced of the use of tests as a sole documentary
> agent if it were easy to use a tool to automatically jump to the appropriate
> test for a method from the source code.
>

Interesting idea. Off the cuff, I can envision a tool that inspects test
methods and adds an "@see" JavaDoc comment to the corresponding method. This
would allow you to hyperlink from the method to its test using a standard
JavaDoc report. I've also used the Eclipse feature of finding all references to
a method to identify which test methods exercise a specific method and then jump
directly to the method.

On a slightly different note, I find that keeping the tests as clean and
expressive as possible helps increase the value of tests as effective
documentation. This paper identifies some common test code smells and
refactorings...

http://www.cwi.nl/~leon/papers/xp2001/xp2001.pdf

Mike
